metadata.title: Popliteal Cysts in Pediatric Patients
anatomical location body part affected: Primarily the knee, at times also affecting the calf and/or ankle
description: A fluid-filled  synovial mass, usually located medially in the popliteal fossa, most often resulting from distension of the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus  bursa. Popliteal cysts occur as a primary condition in children.(10)They can be unilateral or bilateral.(3) In contrast to the adult population, in children these cysts occur without internal derangement and rarely require excision.(6) On occasion, popliteal cysts can occur in athletes due to meniscal tears(7) –Primary cyst  – arises from the bursa in the posterior medial aspect of the knee between the semimembranosus muscle and medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle(1) -Distension of bursa is independent and does not communicate to joint without an intraarticular disorder or knee derangement(3) –Secondary cyst  – communicates directly between the bursa and knee joint, allowing articular fluid to fill the cyst(2,3) -Usually indicates an intraarticular injury or pathology such as a meniscal/ligamentous tear or synovitis(2,4)

Signs and symptoms –Most often, the cyst is an incidental finding on physical examination or the patient or parent becomes aware of cyst and brings to doctor’s attention(8) –The cyst usually develops before age 15, is asymptomatic, and is not associated with knee effusion(8) –Children typically present with a painless mass along the posteromedial aspect of the knee(2) –Synovial inflammation(3) –May complain of mild pain, discomfort, tenderness, or fullness in the posterior aspect of the knee(5) –If the cyst ruptures, diffuse pain and swelling in the calf may be present(5)  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

ICD-10 codes.M66.0: rupture of popliteal cyst (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Description –Primary cyst  – arises from the bursa in the posterior medial aspect of the knee between the semimembranosus muscle and medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle(1) -Distension of bursa is independent and does not communicate to joint without an intraarticular disorder or knee derangement(3) –Secondary cyst  – communicates directly between the bursa and knee joint, allowing articular fluid to fill the cyst(2,3) -Usually indicates an intraarticular injury or pathology such as a meniscal/ligamentous tear or synovitis(2,4)

Signs and symptoms –Most often, the cyst is an incidental finding on physical examination or the patient or parent becomes aware of cyst and brings to doctor’s attention(8) –The cyst usually develops before age 15, is asymptomatic, and is not associated with knee effusion(8) –Children typically present with a painless mass along the posteromedial aspect of the knee(2) –Synovial inflammation(3) –May complain of mild pain, discomfort, tenderness, or fullness in the posterior aspect of the knee(5) –If the cyst ruptures, diffuse pain and swelling in the calf may be present(5)  Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and the physician’s orders
It is important to respect the patient’s subjective complaints of pain during evaluation
Use caution when assessing knee ROM, since this will likely exacerbate the patient’s complaints of pain and other symptoms(1,3,4)

Red flags when evaluating a patient with a popliteal cyst that warrant referral to the physician and/or stopping the evaluation/treatment are the following: fever, chills, night sweats, weight loss, increased complaints of pain with ambulation(1) –In some cases, popliteal cysts may rupture, possibly resulting in infection. Patients may also develop thrombophlebitis from compression of the popliteal vein. Contact the referring physician immediately if any new signs and symptoms arise during the evaluation and/or treatment(3)

If there is clinical concern for deep venous thrombosis (DVT), contact the referring physician immediately so that an ultrasound scan can be performed to properly diagnose the condition and begin treatment intervention(1) –Typical signs and symptoms of DVT(1) -Tenderness of the calf on palpation, leg pain with ambulation, swelling in the leg, increased temperature and/or redness in the leg, and increased pain with ankle dorsiflexion, also known as Homans’ sign

causes: Primary cysts often are often not associated with any knee disorders and may be due to repeated trauma to the bursa frommuscle contraction(4) or a local mechanical irritation of the primary gastrocnemio-semimembranosus  bursa, causing adistension of it(8)

Direct trauma to the bursa or mechanical irritation is the most common cause of popliteal cysts in children because there isgenerally no communication between the bursa and the knee joint in children(3,4,8)

In children the knee joint usually is normal, although in some cases osteochondritis dissecans, meniscus tear, or a synovialpathology may be present, whereas in adults popliteal cysts are almost always accompanied by joint pathology(8)

Incidence–Most popliteal cysts in children occur in those under age 15 and are primary cysts, whereas in adults the majorityof popliteal cysts are secondary cysts due to intraarticular mechanical and degenerative problems or inflammatorydiseases(2,3)–Popliteal cysts are most often diagnosed in children 4–7years old(3,4)

Prevalence–Approximately 6% in children with knee pain who have undergone magnetic imaging studies(3,4)–2.4% of popliteal cyst found in children < 15 years of age are asymptomatic(3)–Most common synovial cyst found in the knee(1)
pathogenesis: A Baker cyst is considered a herniation of the synovium in the knee joint into the popliteal region(6)

Chronic irritation in the knee joint may increase production of synovial fluid, which creates an extension or herniation offluid from the weakened posteromedial joint capsule into the bursa under higher intraarticular pressure. Eventually, theone-way  valve formed by the gastrocnemius-soleus  complex “closes,” trapping the fluid into one of the popliteal bursae(3,4)–The bursa then distends and forms a palpable mass, more commonly in the posteromedial aspect of the popliteal fossa
Anatomically, the lack of supporting structures in the popliteal fossa may predispose this region to cyst formation(4)

Popliteal cysts may extend beyond the deep fascia and the medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle; in some cases the cystmay rupture, causing diffuse pain and/or swelling in the calf due to cyst leakage(4,5)
Occasionally cysts are associated with intra-articular  pathology (osteochondritis dissecans, meniscus tear) or seronegativeor positive arthropathy(8)

Can occur as a result of negative intraarticular knee pressure when the knee is partially flexed with a combination ofpositive pressure during knee extension. This can result in fluid flow towards the cysts from the suprapatellar bursa duringflexion(10)
risk factors: Any condition associated with intraarticular pathology, synovitis, and/or knee joint effusion(1,3,4)–Ligament sprain or tear–Meniscal sprain or tear–Osteochondritisdissecans–Rheumatoid arthritis, infectious arthritis, polyarthritis–Synovitis, villonodular synovitis–Chondromalacia patellae–Chronic low-grade  infection–Persistent capsulitis

overall contraindications precautions: When evaluating a child in whom a popliteal cyst has been diagnosed, contact the referring physician immediately if the child presents with severe knee or leg pain and/or swelling, since this may be indicative of a more serious joint pathology or systemic illness
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Occasionally associated with joint effusion, meniscal injury, or ligament injury in children(8) -Ask patient and/primary caregiver when signs or symptoms were first noticed -Does the patient and/or primary caregiver recall any direct or obvious trauma to the knee joint?(1) -Was the patient evaluated by a physician, or did the patient self-refer? -If a diagnosis of popliteal cyst has been made, what are the physician’s orders? Any restrictions?has the child undergone surgical intervention as a result of another joint pathology such as a meniscal or ligamentous injury? What type?

course of treatment.medical management: Popliteal cysts are rarely aspirated or surgically excised, especially in children(5) Conservative medical management is most often indicated prior to any invasive procedures such as needle aspiration or surgical excision(3) Needle aspiration collapses the cyst by draining the fluid from within; however, if there is an underlying pathology and/or joint disease, further medical intervention may be necessary(4) Popliteal cyst recurrence is likely if the underlying cause is not resolved(1,4) If knee joint effusion is present, the physician may perform needle aspiration in conjunction with an intraarticular corticosteroid injection; however, the cystic fluid is gelatinous and not easily aspirated(1,4) Extreme caution should be taken with cyst aspiration due to the proximity of the neurovascular structures in the popliteal space(1) Surgical excision is not usually necessary for popliteal cysts in children and is reported to be associated with high cyst recurrence rates(8) Surgical excision is attempted only after all other methods have failed and the cyst is sufficiently large and remains symptomatic, or if surgery is necessary to correct the underlying pathology (e.g., arthroscopic surgery to repair a meniscal tear)(4) Arthroscopic surgery combined with repair of the cyst wall using the tendon flap of the medial head of the gastrocnemius musclehas been shown to decrease recurrence rates(9)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed and if they are being taken No evidence found regarding medications for treating popliteal cysts Analgesics such as acetaminophen may be prescribed for pain control if needed  NSAIDs or intraarticular steroids may be considered for inflammation(3,4)
diagnostic tests completed: In general, ultrasonography and MRI are the two most common radiologic methods performed when a popliteal cyst is suspected(2,4)
Radiograph: may show soft tissue density posteriorly and assist with diagnosing any underlying degenerative joint disease, but rarely used to diagnose popliteal cyst(3,4)
Ultrasound: used to differentiate a cyst from a solid tumor or soft tissue mass and to determine size of cyst(3,4)
Doppler ultrasound can differentiate a popliteal cyst from a popliteal vessel aneurysm, thrombophlebitis, or soft tissue tumor (i.e., lipoma, fibroma, fibrosarcoma)(3)
MRI: generally is not indicated unless ambiguity exists and/or an intra-articular pathology is suspected; it is, however, the diagnostic gold standard for visualization of masses about the knee(3,8)
Assists in ruling out solid tumors and defining pathologic changes prior to surgical intervention(4)
A popliteal cyst appears as a well-circumscribed  mass with low signal intensity on T1-weighted  images and high

Arthrography (injection of contrast dye into the knee joint or bursa): May be indicated if a secondary popliteal cyst is suspected since it may not show enlargement of the bursa if there is no communication between the joint and bursa(3,4)
Laboratory tests: generally, not indicated but may be ordered to assist with differential diagnosis if septic arthritis or other infection is suspected
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or complementary/alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture, herbal supplements) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before symptoms come on or are eased) -Flexion and/or extension of the knee may increase complaints of pain or discomfort(1)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -Palpable mass is most often present in the popliteal fossa area
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -Cysts are often asymptomatic unless they rupture or are associated with an intraarticular knee pathology such as a meniscal tear, ligament sprain, or ligament tear(3,5) -May report diffuse/dull achiness, pain, swelling, and/or fullness in the posterior aspect of the knee and/or along the medial joint line, especially when size of the cyst hinders joint ROM(5) -Possible severe calf pain may be reported; indicative of possible ruptured cyst(1) -Large cysts may cause entrapment of the tibial nerve, resulting in signs and symptoms of neuropathy(3)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much) -Typically, children do not report complaints of pain unless there is another underlying pathology such as a ligament sprain or meniscal tear(2,4)self-reported  V AS for children aged 312  years -V AS for pain rating (010  line)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any; also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables -Parents may report that the mass increases and decreases in size; swelling is often painless and often is activity induced, such as standing, walking, squatting, kneeling, running, or jumping(2,5) -Is the cyst most noticeable during activities requiring knee flexion, extension, or both?(1)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of awakenings/night, if any
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician, such as calf swelling, fever, chills, night sweats, weight  loss, pain at night, increased complaints of pain with ambulation, any abnormalities within the calf, or reported severe calf pain Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Ask the patient or primary caregiver if there is a history of any knee joint pathology If so, what if any, intervention was recommended? Does the patient have a history of any systemic illness?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, connective tissue disease, rheumatological disorders, cancer, obesity, heart disease and/or hypertension, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? -Have those activities been limited due to patient’s current condition? -Does the patient attend school? -Has the patient stopped participating in physical education or other forms of exercise? -Does the patient have a job? If so, what are his or her work duties?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient have any difficulty performing ADLs? Degree of functional impairments depends on the size of the popliteal cyst and amount of pain/tenderness. The larger the cyst, the more likely it is associated with more functional limitations, especially ambulation(4)
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does the patient live (e.g., family members, caregivers)? Identify if there are any barriers to independence in the homestairs? If so, number of floors in home? Location of bedroom and bathroom? Entrance to the home? Shower vs. bathtub?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Note if the patient has an increased BMI for age and sex
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient need to use an assistive device such as crutches to alleviate symptoms?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess patient’s static and dynamic balance with one or more of the following tests as deemed appropriate per –Bruininks-Oseretsky  Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2)  balance subscale; Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS) –Due to time constraints, only parts of the PBS, such as Romberg, Sharpened Romberg, and Single Leg Stance, may be performed
relevant tests and measures.circulation: May palpate distal pulses (dorsalis pedis and tibialis posterior arteries). Note if swelling is present and if it increases with activities such as squatting, kneeling, walking, running, or jumpingIf appropriate, assess patient’s ability to properly perform body mechanics such as squatting, lifting, etc.; note any limitations due to painAssess patient’s ability to perform transfers such as sit-to-stand, floor-to-stand,  or getting out of a car without complaints of pain, discomfort –Usually, functional mobility is minimally affected; however, the larger the cyst, the more likely it is to cause functional limitations in activities such as standing, walking, squatting, kneeling, running, or jumping(4)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess patient’s gait and note any significant deviations. May present with an antalgic gait pattern and asymmetrical stance phase, stride length, or step length due to pain during weight-bearing  on the involved extremity or tibial neuropathy(4)Palpate joint line and note any tenderness. Assess integrity of medial and lateral collateral ligaments, cruciate ligaments, patellofemoral joint, and medial and lateral meniscus. Note any abnormality, pain, or tenderness in order to rule out an underlying pathology(4)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Perform bilateral lower extremity manual muscle test (MMT) and note any asymmetry in strength and/or complaints of pain –May also perform bilateral myotomal testing if suspect nerve compression injury due to the proximity of the sciatic nerve in the popliteal fossa and note any muscle atrophy(4)Based on the child’s age, it may be beneficial to assess gross motor development and note if patient is having any difficulty performing age-appropriate  gross motor skills. This can be performed formally with an age-appropriate standardized test such as the Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2),  the BOT-2, or a screen such as Battelle Development Inventory Screening, Ages and Stages Questionnaire
observation inspection palpation includi: Swelling is more obvious when palpating the knee in full extension(8)

Foucher sign: Place patient in prone with knee extended and then gradually flex the knee to 90° and palpate mass(3,4) -Cyst may be firm on palpation with knee extension and may soften or disappear with 45° of knee flexion

Ruptured cysts are typically very painful and associated with swelling over the calf and/or medial malleolus(3) -Commonly mistaken for DVT(1) -Rupture typically occurs in adults, as well as those with rheumatoid and degenerative arthritis(1) -Cysts can extend into the thigh or leg, or there may be multiple satellite cysts along the leg and even into the foot(4)

Patellar ballottement test to assess for joint effusion(1) -Place patient in supine and apply pressure inferiorly on the patella while palpating for “bogginess” around the patellofemoral joint -If “bogginess” is present, this indicates increased fluid in the suprapatellar pouch over the patella
relevant tests and measures.posture: Visual inspection of patient’s standing posture (anterior, posterior, and lateral view of patient), noting any asymmetry and/or deviations such as genu valgum/varus, calcaneal valgus/varus, patellar position (squinting), hyperextension of the knees, pelvic height, subtalar neutral (in supine) non-weight-bearing
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess AROM and PROM/muscle length testing for bilateral lower extremities –Knee ROM is usually within normal limits but may be limited if associated with an underlying intraarticular pathology(1) -Knee flexion may be limited if cyst is large -Ankle ROM may be decreased in the presence of a ruptured cyst in conjunction with an enlarged calf –Important to assess muscle length/flexibility for gastrocnemius-soleus,  hamstrings, iliopsoas, quadriceps, and tensor fasciae latae due to the direct relationship with the knee
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess bilateral patellar and Achilles reflexes, noting any abnormality/asymmetry due to the proximity of the sciatic nerve in the popliteal fossa(4)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess bilateral extremity dermatomal testing due to the proximity of the sciatic nerve in the popliteal fossa. Rule out tibial neuropathy(3,4)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Transillumination may help to clinically distinguish a popliteal cyst from a solid mass –In order to perform this technique, the patient needs to be in a dark room. The therapist takes a bright light and shines it directly on the area to be assessed. Areas abnormally filled with air or fluid will light up(3)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: May indicate patient’s ability to follow multistep commands based on the child’s age and/or other diagnoses (e.g., attention deficit disorder, ADHD, sensory integration dysfunction)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regards to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Popliteal cysts that are asymptomatic often do not need treatment intervention(5) Conservative treatment is recommended for patients who present with complaints of pain or discomfort with mobility(5) If there is an underlying intraarticular pathology (i.e., meniscus tear) associated with the popliteal cyst, treatment for that pathology should be initiated; the cyst should decrease in size and become asymptomatic as the underlying pathology is being properly addressed(5) Surgical excision should be avoided unless the cyst fails to resolve, enlarges rapidly, or causes significant symptoms(2) –In rare cases, large popliteal cysts that do not respond to treatment intervention may need to be surgically excised; referral to a pediatric orthopedist would be indicated at this time(5)
assessment plan of care.rule out: If patient does not respond to typical treatment intervention and remains symptomatic, it is important that the physical therapist communicate directly with the referring physician Other conditions that need to be ruled out with diagnostic testing are infection/abscess, lipoma, liposarcoma, fibroma, hematoma, DVT, vascular tumor, xanthoma, popliteal vein varices, ganglion cyst, thrombophlebitis, and muscular herniation(3)
prognosis: The most common complications of popliteal cysts(4) –Dissecting cysts into the calf that may or may not rupture, leading to calf, ankle, and foot ecchymosis -When the cyst ruptures, it produces a “pseudothrombophlebitis syndrome” due to compression of the popliteal vein, resulting in intense calf pain and swelling without associated DVT –Peripheral neuropathy or lower extremity claudication, but these are less likely to occur(4) –If the cyst becomes infected, septic arthritis of the knee can result if intraarticular-bursa  communication exists(4)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: A referral to a pediatric orthopedist is indicated if an intraarticular pathology is suspected and undiagnosed by the physician (e.g., meniscal tear, ligament sprain) and/or the patient remains symptomatic despite typical treatment intervention
treatment summary: Physical therapy is not indicated if the patient is asymptomatic; popliteal cysts tend to resolve spontaneously in children(3,4,8)

Stretching and resistance exercises to improve lower extremity muscle strength may be necessary, especially for patients who present with degenerative or inflammatory arthropathy, ligament injuries, or meniscal injuries(4)
Gait training is indicated for patients who present with an antalgic gait pattern as well as functional mobility limitations such as but not limited to squatting or stair negotiation(4)
Ice, compression can be applied in the initial treatment and rehabilitation of the cyst but are rarely required as the cyst tends to involute spontaneously in most children(4)

In children, surgical intervention is not typically warranted(8) . maintenance or prevention: Avoid or modify any activities that appear related to increased swelling and/or pain (e.g., kneeling, squatting, and crawling) until cyst begins to subside
